title: A Burning Attraction
content: As far as I know, there’s no competition among linguists for the most durable figures of speech, but, if there were, the simile “like a moth to a flame” might be a top contender. The fact that the phrase and the biological phenomenon on which it’s based are so universally familiar is probably why a recent paper by Fabian et al. (2024), titled “Why Flying Insects Gather at Artificial Light,” managed to rack up an Altmetric score (a measure of the online attention paid to a specific article) of 3,908. This score is astronomically high; to put it in context, it places the article in the 99th percentile, ranking 20th out of the 338,056 tracked papers published at about the same time. The attention was global—more than 500 news outlets ran stories about the paper online, and interested readers could find these stories not only in English, but also in Spanish, French, Portuguese, Italian, German, Danish, Russian, Croatian, Estonian, Indonesian, Chinese, Japanese, Greek, and more than a few other languages that I couldn’t recognize right away.
